TEXT: The applicants , Mr PERSON , ORG and their son PERSON PERSON , are NORP nationals , who were born in DATE and DATE , respectively , and live in GPE . They are represented before the Court by PERSON , legal adviser of ORG in GPE , and Mr PERSON , barrister and professor of law at ORG . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , Director of ORG of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

Mr PERSON , the first applicant , was born in GPE . At the time the application was lodged with the ORG , he was married to Ms Ljubov Mikolenko , the second applicant , who was also born in GPE . Their son , Mr PERSON , the third applicant , was born in GPE . The first and the second applicant have also another son , PERSON , who was born in DATE . He has a permanent residence permit in GPE .

The first applicant served in the NORP and NORP armed forces from DATE , when he retired as a warrant officer . From DATE to DATE he served in the territory of GPE . In DATE he was transferred to military unit no . DATE in the NORP military district . The first and the second applicants have been living in GPE since then .
Since DATE the applicants have been registered as inhabitants in the apartment at GPE puiestee CARDINAL - CARDINAL in GPE .
On DATE GPE and GPE concluded a treaty on the withdrawal of NORP troops from NORP territory .

On DATE the first applicant was assigned to the reserve forces by the decree of the commander of the military unit no . DATE . According to the transcript of the decree , he was discharged from the military unit and excluded from the provision of all types of supplies as of DATE .
As from DATE the first applicant worked as a manager in a private company . The second applicant has been working as a nurse in DATE .
On DATE the first applicant submitted an application for a residence permit in GPE . At that time his parents were living in GPE .

The first applicant applied for a flat in GPE within the framework of an aid programme provided by GPE ( GPE ) . On DATE he signed a written commitment in this connection . The form of the commitment was in LANGUAGE . In the form , signed by the first applicant , it was stated that he wished to take part in the programme for providing housing for officers of the NORP armed forces . It was further stated that if he would receive housing in the context of the programme , he and his family would vacate the dwelling that was at their disposal in the NORP country and that in the future he would be able to visit the NORP countries only as a foreigner on general basis . Furthermore , it was stated that the applicant had no housing in GPE , that he had not paid anyone for the right to take part in the programme and that he was aware that the housing in the context of the programme would be provided free of charge . It was confirmed that the dwelling he possessed in the NORP country had not been privatised or sold and that he had not received any payment for it .

On DATE the second applicant privatised ( purchased on favourable conditions from the municipality ) the apartment at GPE puiestee CARDINAL - CARDINAL in GPE . According to the data in the land register , as at DATE , this apartment was still in the ownership of the second applicant .

In the form filled out on the basis of the interview conducted with the first applicant by a staff of the aid programme on DATE concerning the grounds of participation in the programme and the amount of financing by the bank , it was noted that the first applicant was entitled to enrol in the programme . According to the document , in reply to the question how he would describe his and his family ’s feelings in connection with leaving the NORP countries , he chose the following answer from among the multiple choices : “ we are very happy about the departure ” . In reply to the question why he had chosen GPE as the possible new residence , he answered : “ relatives ” . To the question what he would miss most when moving to the new place , he replied colleagues of his military unit .

On DATE the first applicant , holder of the certificate SP-CARDINAL , issued by the aid programme , concluded a purchase agreement for an apartment at FAC CARDINAL with GPE . According to the agreement , the price of the apartment was MONEY ( USD ) , of which CARDINAL was to be paid by ORG for ORG and ORG CARDINAL by the first applicant .

On DATE the apartment purchased by the first applicant was registered as his property by the relevant bureau of GPE . According to the information from ORG of GPE , submitted by the respondent Government in the context of the proceedings concerning the applicants’ legal aid request , as at CARDINAL DATE the apartment was still in the ownership of the first applicant .

On DATE the first and the second applicants were granted temporary residence permits in GPE for DATE . The third applicant received a temporary residence permit on DATE . The date of its expiry was the same as DATE of the residence permits of his parents , i.e. DATE .
On DATE the temporary residence permits of the applicants were extended until DATE . In DATE their residence permits were further extended until DATE .

On DATE an amendment to LAW ( PERSON seadus ) entered into force so as to exclude the possibility of issuing or extending residence permits for persons who had committed themselves to leaving GPE or who had received an accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme .

On DATE and DATE the Minister of the ORG issued orders by which the applicants were refused extensions of their residence permits . The refusals were based on CARDINAL grounds . Firstly , the first applicant had served as a professional member of the armed forces of a foreign country and had retired from there . This ground applied also to the second and the third applicants as family members ( spouse and minor child ) of the first applicant . Secondly , the applicants had committed themselves to leaving GPE and had received accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme .

The applicants submitted a complaint to ORG ( PERSON NORP ) , which , by a judgment of DATE , dismissed the complaint . It observed that the applicants had committed themselves to leaving GPE and had received accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . According to LAW such persons could not be granted extensions of residence permits .

In an appeal to ORG ( Tallinna GPE ) the applicants contested the retroactive application of the provisions of LAW so as to refuse extensions of residence permits of persons who had committed themselves to leaving GPE and who had received an accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . LAW did not contain the disputed provisions at the time when the applicants participated in the aid programme and received accommodation in GPE . They argued that their legitimate expectation rights and the principle of legal certainty had been violated . They claimed that they should have been exceptionally granted residence permits under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .

On DATE the appeal was heard at ORG . The applicants did not appear at the hearing . On DATE before the hearing the first applicant had submitted to ORG a request to adjourn the hearing due to his deteriorated health condition . ORG , nevertheless , held the hearing . It found that the first applicant had not provided a medical certificate and that he had failed to specify the reasons why he had been hindered from taking part in the hearing . The second and third applicants had not requested that the hearing be adjourned .

By a judgment of DATE ORG upheld the judgment of ORG . It noted that the first applicant had served in the NORP army at the time the treaty concerning withdrawal of the NORP armed forces from GPE had been concluded ( DATE ) . Accordingly , he was subject to removal , together with his family members , under the treaty . ORG also found that it was established that the applicants had received accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme and that they had committed themselves to leaving GPE .

In an appeal to ORG ( NORP ) the applicants complained that their right to take part in the hearing at ORG had been violated . They maintained that their commitment to leave the country had not been made to the NORP authorities . They also complained about the retroactive application of LAW and that they had been discriminated against , since several persons who had taken part in the aid programme had , in fact , been granted extensions of residence permits .

On DATE ORG upheld the judgments in substance , with modifications to their reasoning . ORG rejected the complaint concerning the inability of the applicants to take part in the hearing at ORG . It noted that the ORG requests to adjourn the hearing had been granted repeatedly and found that , according to LAW ORG seadustik ) , ORG could have rejected the appeal on the grounds of their failure to appear .

With respect to the substance of the appeal , ORG found that the interference with the applicants’ right to family life had been proportionate to the aim pursued by the State – to ensure that the professional servicemen of the former NORP army be withdrawn from GPE . ORG deemed the fact that GPE had not been a party of the international aid programme irrelevant to the legitimacy of the legislation prohibiting the extension of residence permits for persons who had benefited from the programme .

On DATE the third applicant was granted a temporary residence permit in GPE with validity until DATE , since he had attained the age of majority and thus could no longer be considered as a family member of a retired officer of the armed forces .
On DATE the first and the second applicants dissolved their marriage .

On DATE the Citizenship and Migration Board ( Kodakondsus- ja GPE – hereinafter “ the Board ” ) ordered the first applicant to leave the country on DATE at the latest . On CARDINAL DATE the first applicant lodged a complaint with ORG requesting that the order be invalidated .

On DATE the ORG refused to consider the second applicant ’s request for a residence permit on an exceptional basis . ORG noted that , according to the applicable legislation , a request for a residence permit had to be submitted , as a rule , to an NORP foreign representation . It established no circumstances which prevented the second applicant from doing so .

On an unspecified date in DATE the first applicant submitted to ORG a request to reopen the proceedings ( teistmisavaldus ) and to quash the previous administrative court judgments . He claimed that he was a subject of the NORP - Russian agreement concerning the social guarantees to retired military personnel of the NORP armed forces in GPE and , therefore , he and his family members could have lawfully been refused an extension of the residence permit only in the event that it had been established that he posed a threat to the national security of GPE . On DATE ORG refused the request .

On DATE ORG dismissed the first applicant ’s request to invalidate the DATE order of ORG . He appealed against the judgment to ORG . ORG has not been furnished with information concerning the outcome of the appeal .

On DATE the police arrested the first applicant for illegally residing in GPE . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) imposed on him a fine of CARDINAL kroons ( MONEY ) . Apparently he was released after the hearing , having been kept in detention for TIME .

On DATE ORG decided , upon a request by the police , that the first applicant had to be taken to a deportation centre for execution of the deportation order . ORG authorised his detention for DATE starting from DATE , his immediate deportation being impossible , since he had not presented a valid identification document ( the applicant could not remember where his valid passport was ) .

According to a medical certificate submitted to the ORG , the first applicant was hospitalised DATE . He has been detained in the deportation centre since DATE . His detention has been extended by ORG once DATE . ORG has been , unsuccessfully , attempting to expel him to GPE . On DATE the first and second applicants lodged new complaints to the ORG , concerning the first applicant ’s prolonged detention and the conditions of detention in the deportation centre . These complaints have been registered as a separate application ( no . CARDINAL ) .

In the meantime , on DATE the ORG refused the first applicant ’s request for a residence permit . He challenged the refusal in ORG , which on DATE dismissed the complaint . The judgment was upheld by ORG .
On DATE the second applicant was served by ORG with an order to leave the country . On DATE she was refused a residence permit .
On DATE the ORG again refused the first applicant ’s request for a residence permit .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( PERSON seadus ) listed the instances in which a residence permit could not be issued or extended . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) provided that a permit could not be issued or extended , if the foreigner applying for it had served as a professional member of the armed forces of a foreign state or had been assigned to the reserve forces thereof or had retired therefrom . DATE ) provided that a residence permit could also not be issued or extended for the spouse and minor children of a person referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) . LAW ) , however , provided that , as an exception , a temporary residence permit could be issued or extended for the foreigner concerned if this was not excluded on some other grounds listed in the same provision .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of the Foreigners’ Act provided that a residence permit could not in any case be issued or extended , if the person concerned had , inter alia , committed himself or herself to leaving GPE or had received accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . This provision was adopted on DATE and entered into force on DATE . It was subject to an amendment in DATE , which does not appear to have relevance to the present case .

According to the Government of GPE , in DATE the President of GPE and the President of the GPE agreed to undertake a project for providing CARDINAL units of housing for NORP military officers demobilized from the NORP countries or elsewhere outside GPE .

The Government submitted to the ORG a copy of “ NORP Military Officer Resettlement Program . ORG ” and “ NORP Military Officer Resettlement Program . ORG . ORG ” . These information materials appear to have been handed out by the NORP side in ORG to the participating NORP officers .

According to the information materials , the NORP Military Officer Resettlement Programme had been set up in order to provide CARDINAL units of housing for NORP military officers demobilised mainly from the NORP countries . CARDINAL of the units of housing had to be constructed , whereas the rest of the housing units had to be provided through a housing certificate programme .

In order to take part in the ORG , the officers had to present a discharge order , passport , official verification of the family size and composition , official verification of current residence in the LOC and a signed application for participation in the programme containing declarations that upon obtaining housing under this programme , the officer and his family would vacate their present dwelling(s ) in the LOC countries and would not seek permanent residency in any of ORG , and from then on would enter ORG only as foreign guests . The officers had to declare that they and their families did not own housing in GPE nor would they own , privatise or sell any dwellings in the LOC and would not receive any payments in connection with vacating any dwelling . The officers declared their understanding that if they were found to be eligible to participate in the ORG and if all ORG ’s terms and conditions were met , they would receive appropriate apartments ( in the framework of the housing construction programme ) or financial assistance for the purchase of housing units ( in the framework of the housing certificate programme ) .

In order to obtain a registration of residence ( propiska ) in the Passport Desk for their new apartment , the officers had to present their NORP Passport and the NORP passports for all family members along with proof of cancellation of their registration of residency ( vypiska ) for all members of the family in the LOC . Officers had to move in DATE after notification by ORG or by the local administration , otherwise their apartments could be reassigned .
Participation in the ORG was voluntary ; no enrolment fee was required .

After the independence of GPE was restored on DATE , the NORP troops remained in the country . Following the dissolution of GPE , GPE assumed jurisdiction over its armed forces . On DATE GPE and GPE concluded a treaty on the withdrawal of the NORP troops from the NORP territory and on the conditions of their temporary stay in GPE . On DATE , GPE and GPE concluded an agreement concerning the social guarantees to the retired military personnel of the armed forces of GPE on the territory of GPE . LAW and the LAW entered into force on DATE , having been subject to temporary application from DATE of signing , that is , from DATE .

According to the LAW , ORG undertook to withdraw from GPE , by DATE , all military personnel who were in the active service of the NORP armed forces . Family members of the military personnel in active service who did not have a dwelling in GPE were allowed to remain in GPE for DATE .

The Agreement provided that retired military personnel , i.e. persons discharged from the army service and receiving pension , and their family members could apply for residence permit in GPE . ORG could deny a residence permit due to a threat to national security .
